owl:Ontology.owl:description: An ontology about vertebrates and some of their features

owl:ObjectProperty.owl:description: A relation between animals, which animal preys on and eats which.
A relation specifying what the body temperature is.
A property specifying what the conservation status of an animal is.
A property specifying food habits of animals.
A property specifying animals' body coverings.
A relation specifying tameness of animals.
Representing taxonomic ranks of a given creature; i.e. is a class, a phylum, a kingdom etc.
A property specifying what kind of climate(s) animals live in.

owl:DatatypeProperty.owl:description: A data property specifying aquatic habitats of animals.
A data property specifying the average length of animals.
A data property specifying average height of animals.
A data property specifying average lifespan of animals.
A data property specifying the class names of animals.
A data property specifying color(s) of animals.
A data property specifying the common names of animals.
A data property specifying common English names for animals.
A data property specifying the Family names of animals.
A data property specifying the genus names of animals.
A data property specifying the habitat of animals.
A data property specifying the kingdom names of animals.
A data property specifying the order names of animals.
A data property specifying common Farsi name for animals.
A data property specifying the phylum names of animals.
A data property specifying the species names of animals.
A data property specifying the taxonomic names of animals.
A data property specifying terrestrial habitats of animals.
A data property specifying the top speed of animals.

owl:Class.rdfs:label: Animal
owl:Class.owl:description: Representing all living things categorized under the kingdom Animalia.

This is a class representing body temperature of animals. It has two individuals: changing and constant. Constant body temperature includes to warm blooded creatures and changing body temperature indludes cold blooded ones.
Representing different types of climates animals could live in. Class Climate includes four instances: Arctic, Tropical, Moderate, Cold.

owl:Class.rdfs:seeAlso: Representing the conservation status of animals.

owl:Class.rdfs:label: DomainThing
owl:Class.owl:description: Representing our main concept of interest and class hierarchy: Animals, or to be more specific vertebrates.
Representing the conservation status(es) considered as disappeared. It has two instances: One representing extinct as in extinct in the wild and the other, as in completely extinct.
Representing the coservation status(es) considered as safe, i.e. plenty of animals exist if the conservation status of an animal is of type lower risk. It includes only one instance: LeastConcern.

Representing one of the three main groups of living mammals; whose distinctive characteristic is that most of the young are carried in a pouch. Well-known marsupials include kangaroos, wallabies, koalas, possums, opossums, wombats, and Tasmanian devils.
We represent any animal who is not categorized as vertebrate with this class.

Representing one of the three main groups of living mammals; whose distinctive feature compared to the other two categories lies in the fact that the fetus is carried in the uterus of its mother to a relatively late stage of development.
Representing the conservation status(es) considered as guarded and Threatened. It includes three instances: CriticallyEndangered, Endangered, NearEndangered.
Representing conservation status of the so-called animal has not yet been examined. This is either due to lack of data, or simply because it has never been evaluated before.

owl:Class.rdfs:label: ValueThing
owl:Class.owl:description: Representing classes which describe information about our main concept of interest; aka animals and specifically vertebrates.

Vertebrates comprise all species of animals within the subphylum Vertebrata (i.e. chordates with backbones). Vertebrates represent the overwhelming majority of the phylum Chordata, with currently about 69,276 species described.
